These are the major site security measures:



Fence with barbed wire surrounding the site

Security camera(s) in selected areas

Main entrance staffed with guards on a 24 hour basis

All other gates are either locked or guarded but may be opened in the event of emergency egress

Warning signs



It is the policy of FirstEnergy to assure the safe operation of the facility which is designed and built to good engineering practices that incorporate methods or principles in accordance with applicable industry standards.  Some of these standards include ASME code for process piping, B31.3, and ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel code, Section VIII.   



Accident History



There have been no accidents.  



Emergency Response



There is a written emergency response plan that is coordinated with the Jefferson County LEPC and the local fire departments.  Selected site response personnel are Hazwoper trained.    



Emergency response planning has long been an integral part of operations at Sammis.  Regulations under OSHA, EPA, Coast Guard, and Ohio EPA have required the site to develop and implement procedures to plan for and respond to emergency situations at the plant whether due to natural disasters, storms, exposure to releases or harm/damage resulting from potentially flammable or explosive materials.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



In response to the 5 year RMP review and revalidation, the following action items are planned to be conducted by First Energy.

 

Since both the ASME code for process piping, B31.3 and the ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel code, Section VIII have been recently updated since the primary engineering evaluation for the storage tanks and piping was conducted in 2009, First Energy plans to conduct an engineering evaluation

with respect to the updated ASME code for process piping, B31.3, and ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel code, Section VIII standards to determine the implications for existing equipment, if there are any.



Testing and maintenance procedures for the E-stop system are planned to be developed.

 

Description of Release Scenarios

#2.  Aqueous Ammonia Storage Unloading Station - Rural - 57,000 gallons
